opened_prs.body:
Depends on https://github.com/alloy-rs/evm/pull/17

For reuse in payload building, we need to 
a) distinguish between tx validation errors and fatal evm errors (e.g comming from database)
b) have access to `InvalidTxError` to decide whether we should skip tx descendants https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/626f3b566f01d13d9ff0aca897e21b6c6bfdebda/crates/ethereum/payload/src/lib.rs#L287-L303

With this PR `BlockValidationError::InvalidTx` would only contain boxed `invalidTxError`, and any other errors would be stored in `BlockExecutionError::Internal` variant

opened_prs.title: [wip] feat: `HeaderBuilder`
opened_prs.body:
RIght now the only type which knows how to construct a header is `PayloadBuilder`. This is unconvinient because we have peripheral usecases requiring constructing a block which ideally should not be embedded into PayloadBuilder logic. Examples of such usecases are complex RPC functionality (`eth_simulateV1`, pending block building), `debug.reorg` flags.

This PR experiments with a simpler trait providing access to header building logic. The idea is that caller can construct payload attributes and block body, delegate the execution to block executor, and then simply invoke `HeaderBuilder` to finish block building.

labels.description: Related to reth's use as a library

opened_issues.body:
The node builder architecture currently uses `BuilderComponentsAdapter` as the internal state holder for `NodeBuilderWithComponents`. This adapter manages:

- Node configuration (`NodeConfig` with chain spec)
- Type system adaptation (`NodeTypesAdapter`)
- Component building (through a generic `ComponentsBuilder`)
- Node extensions (through `AddOns`)

Introducing a trait boundary could simplify the interaction between these components.

opened_issues.title: feat: configuration of the tokio runtime

labels.name: D-good-first-issue
labels.description: Nice and easy! A great choice to get started

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

Apologies if I'm missing something here, but is there a way to configure Reth's tokio runtime?  Some users may benefit from finer control over Reth's internal runtime.  

For example, if you want to do some CPU-intensive work alongside Reth (eg as part of an execution extension), it would be beneficial to have a dedicated threadpool.   Reth's tokio runtime uses worker threads = num cores by default, which could be problematic in some cases.

<!--
For example, if you want to run a CPU-intensive task alongside Reth (eg an execution extension), there is no way to ensure that it will run in a dedicated thread/threadpool.  This could cause problems by preventing the executor from driving other tasks.  While `spawn_blocking(..)` is appropriate for lightweight blocking tasks that will complete on their own, [is not suitable for running multiple or long-running CPU-bound tasks](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/task/fn.spawn_blocking.html).  See also https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/#cpu-bound-tasks-and-blocking-code.  Currently, the only exposed configuration of the runtime is through tokio's `TOKIO_WORKER_THREADS` environment variable.
-->

Current runtime configuration:

https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/cec1c11ece5f6da30215c06a7e3f61c737020f65/crates/cli/runner/src/lib.rs#L146

Example addition to the Cli API:

```rust
let runtime = tokio::runtime::Builder::new_multi_thread()
    .worker_threads(4)
    .max_blocking_threads(256)
    .enable_all()
    .build()
    .unwrap();
// proposed api: with_runtime(runtime, launcher)
Cli::parse().with_runtime(runtime, |builder, _| { /* ... */});
```

This should be pretty simple so I'm happy to take this on if deemed worthwhile.  Thanks!

opened_issues.title: Refactor and extract block execution to `alloy-evm`

labels.name: S-needs-design
labels.description: This issue requires design work to think about how it would best be accomplished

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

We want to create a reusable abstraction for block execution.

It is llikely that core interface for the abstraction would be `BlockExecutionStrategy` https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/3485ce45be8e90c04b8d42d172f0d899ef62cb1d/crates/evm/src/execute.rs#L169-L200

For now the abstraction should simply allow obtaining all relevant state transitions for a block without requiring caller to hold an entire block type, and with the ability to determine transactions set dynamically (for payload building)

To extract it we'd need to move over `EthereumHardforks`/`OpHardforks` to https://github.com/alloy-rs/hardforks. Also we'd need to extract some of the `EthChainSpec` methods to a separate trait in `alloy-evm` (`base_fee_params_at`, `blob_params_at`).

This is till blocked by more preparation on reth side. It would make sense to extract `BlockExecutionStrategy`s once we are already reusing them in both block execution and payload building.


### Additional context

_No response_

opened_issues.title: Excessive database reads for HashedAccounts table

labels.name: S-needs-triage
labels.description: This issue needs to be labelled

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the bug

Hey everyone,

I've been trying to understand how the new multiproof function in Reth 1.2 works with trie and hashed account walkers, and I'm struggling to understand why there are an excessive number of database reads for HashedAccounts. I must be missing something, but here are my findings:

To simplify the issue, I started with a very basic use case: I synced my node to the 1M'th block and have a single sample block with 1 simple transaction (xfer). I'm calling the **engine_newPayload** API with this block, which only involves 3 accounts (sender, recipient, and beneficiary where beneficiary is 0). For this particular case:

I've followed the code through ParallelProof::multiproof method, which is where the magic happens, and focused on the main loop: "_account_node_iter.try_next()_"
    _while let Some(account_node) = account_node_iter.try_next().map_err(ProviderError::Database)?_

These are the number of reads from tables during this operation:
 **PlainAccountState**: 6 reads
 **AccountsTrie**: 23 reads
 **HashedAccounts**: 354 reads

I can share all the details, but what I'm observing is that during trie traversal, for every iteration step, the code tries to load the next **HashedAccounts** row and compare the hashed key's nibble with the trie walker's current nibble, only to discard the **HashedAccounts** row after setting "_current_walker_key_checked_" to false:
    _if self.walker.key().is_some_and(|key| key < &Nibbles::unpack(hashed_key)) {_

As far as I understand, this is done to ensure that the next hashed account is greater than the current walker's key, i.e., we have a branch node to process before the leaf.

What I don't understand at this point is:

1. In the **AccountsTrie**, we have three mask fields: _state_mask_, _tree_mask_, and _hash_mask_, along with all the hash values for subtrees below. Aren't these fields there to make traversal easier, faster, and more space efficient? Shouldn't we be able to complete the traversal with these all the way down to our leaves? Why do we need to keep checking whether there is a leaf greater than our current trie walk cursor by loading the HashedAccounts row for every iteration?

2. Since our **AccountsTrie** has all the hashes and appropriate masks to interpret the ownership of these hashes, why do we end up reading so many **HashedAccounts**? Shouldn't we only need to read what's required to compute the new proof, i.e., only the leaf nodes right below the last branch above our target leaf, or in other words, all the neighbors of our target leaf node?

Am I missing something here?

opened_issues.title: Filter transactions against supervisor - block building
opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

### Describe the feature

- If interop hardfork is active, after executing built block:
- Extract `ExecutingMessage`s from resulting logs (will be 1 or none per log)
- Make RPC call to supervisor for validating `ExecutingMessage`s
- Remove transactions from block that supervisor deems invalid, and add to the tx pools bad import cache

### Additional context

https://github.com/op-rs/maili/blob/4c2060a2761a571993762bc6b420d2fd6a5e96f7/crates/interop/src/message.rs#L27-L32
https://github.com/op-rs/maili/blob/4c2060a2761a571993762bc6b420d2fd6a5e96f7/crates/rpc/src/traits.rs#L25-L66

This feature is designed especially for sequencer, and hence for beefy machines.

### Additional context

_No response_

opened_issues.title: Filter transactions against supervisor - tx pool

labels.name: S-blocked
labels.description: This cannot more forward until something else changes

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

- If interop hardfork is active:
- Execute transactions in transaction pool on current state using `BlockExecutionStrategy`
- Extract `ExecutingMessage`s from resulting logs (will be 1 or none per log)
- Make RPC call to supervisor for validating `ExecutingMessage`s
- Remove transactions from pool that supervisor deems invalid, and add to bad import cache

### Additional context

https://github.com/op-rs/maili/blob/4c2060a2761a571993762bc6b420d2fd6a5e96f7/crates/interop/src/message.rs#L27-L32
https://github.com/op-rs/maili/blob/4c2060a2761a571993762bc6b420d2fd6a5e96f7/crates/rpc/src/traits.rs#L25-L66

This feature is designed especially for sequencer, and hence for beefy machines.

opened_issues.title: Rework FillTxEnv

labels.name: A-execution
labels.description: Related to the Execution and EVM

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

we should rework this a bit

https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/1804bbea6e53ec35606b8b6e87c4f0f624ee75fc/crates/primitives-traits/src/transaction/execute.rs#L5-L9

this used `fill(&mut Txenv)` due to how revm was previously structured where you had to do `tx.fill(env.tx_env_mut())`

this can now be changed to something like

```rust
trait IntoTxEnv {
   
   fn to_tx_env(tx: Recovered<&Self>) -> TxEnv
    
   fn into_tx_env(tx: Recovered<Self>) -> TxEnv 
   
} 
```

perhaps there's an easier way to design this, conversion, maybe even flip it on TxEnv (From<Tx>) perhaps that would allow more flexibility.

we likely need this in alloy-evm for utils like: https://github.com/alloy-rs/evm/issues/14

### Additional context

_No response_

closed_prs.title: refactor: use Recovered<Tx> when setting up TxEnv
closed_prs.body:
Based on https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pull/14480

Towards https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/14551

Changes all `Tx -> TxEnv` conversions to operate on `Recovered<Tx>` instead of passing sender separately. This should be better for the API because we can now hide this behind a `FillTxEnv`/`IntoTxEnv` trait and have `fn transact(&self, tx: impl IntoTxEnv<Self::Tx>)` directly on Evm. This would not have been possible with `transact(tx, sender)` API
